title: Kikai Caldera
meta_title: Kikai Caldera — Eruption History, Supervolcano Status & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Kikai is a 19 km wide submarine caldera south of Kyushu, Japan. Its VEI 7 eruption ~6,300 years ago devastated prehistoric Japan. Full eruption history and facts.

quick_answer.what: Kikai is a mostly submerged, 19-km-wide volcanic caldera located in the East China Sea near the northern end of the Ryukyu Islands, approximately 50 km south of Kyushu, Japan.
quick_answer.status: Active — mild explosive eruptions continue from Iodake lava dome on Satsuma-Iōjima island. Most recently active in 2025.
quick_answer.famous_for: The cataclysmic Akahoya eruption approximately 7,300 years ago (VEI 7), one of the largest Holocene eruptions on Earth, which sent pyroclastic flows 100 km across the sea and depopulated southern Kyushu for centuries.
quick_answer.danger_level: Classified among Japan's most hazardous calderas. A repeat VEI 7 eruption — though improbable within any human planning horizon — could threaten over 100 million people across southern Japan.

overview.content: Kikai is a large, predominantly submarine caldera measuring approximately 19 km across, situated in the East China Sea near the northern end of the Ryukyu Islands, roughly 50 km south of the main Japanese island of Kyushu. It ranks among the most volcanologically significant calderas on Earth, principally because of the catastrophic VEI 7 eruption approximately 7,300 years ago — known as the Akahoya eruption — which produced pyroclastic flows that traveled 100 km across open water to reach southern Kyushu and blanketed the Japanese archipelago in ash as far north as Hokkaido, some 1,500 km away. That event, one of the largest volcanic eruptions of the Holocene, effectively depopulated southern and central Kyushu for several centuries. Today, the caldera rim breaks the sea surface as the small islands of Satsuma-Iōjima and Take-shima, while post-caldera volcanism has built the Iodake rhyolitic lava dome and the Inamuradake scoria cone on Satsuma-Iōjima. Activity continues: mild-to-moderate phreatic and phreatomagmatic explosions from Iodake occur regularly, most recently in December 2025. Though the probability of another caldera-forming supereruption is considered extremely low, Kikai's sheer destructive potential places it among Japan's most closely watched volcanic systems. The caldera sits along the Ryukyu Arc, a subduction zone where the Philippine Sea Plate dives beneath the Eurasian Plate, providing a sustained supply of volatile-rich magma capable of highly explosive eruptions.

geology_and_formation.content: The Kikai volcanic complex owes its existence to the subduction of the Philippine Sea Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate along the Ryukyu Trench. This plate boundary, extending roughly 1,200 km from Kyushu to Taiwan, generates a chain of volcanic islands and submarine volcanoes collectively known as the Ryukyu Volcanic Arc. At Kikai's latitude, the subducting slab reaches depths of approximately 100–150 km, sufficient to trigger dehydration melting that feeds silica-rich magma chambers beneath the caldera floor. The present 19-km-wide caldera was formed primarily during the Akahoya eruption around 7,300 years ago (radiocarbon-corrected; recorded in the database as ~4350 BCE). That event ejected an estimated 150–170 km³ of dense rock equivalent (DRE) of rhyolitic material — pumice, ash, and pyroclastic flows — making it comparable in scale to the eruption of Tambora in 1815 and significantly larger than the 1991 eruption of Pinatubo. The collapse of the magma chamber during the eruption created the submarine caldera basin visible today. Prior to the Akahoya eruption, a pre-caldera volcanic edifice existed at this location, but the cataclysmic collapse largely destroyed it. Post-caldera volcanism has been constructive: the Iodake (Iwo-dake) lava dome — a steep-sided mass of rhyolitic lava — grew on the eastern end of Satsuma-Iōjima, while the Inamuradake scoria cone formed from basaltic-to-andesitic eruptions nearby. Submarine lava domes have also been detected on the caldera floor. In 2018, researchers from Kobe University announced the discovery of a massive lava dome on the seafloor inside the caldera, approximately 32 km³ in volume, suggesting continued magmatic activity beneath the ocean surface. This discovery reignited scientific and public discussion about Kikai's long-term volcanic potential. The rock types are dominantly rhyolitic, which is characteristic of highly explosive caldera systems — the high silica content produces viscous magma capable of trapping gas until catastrophic release.

eruption_history_overview.content: The Smithsonian Global Volcanism Program records 30 eruptions for Kikai, spanning from approximately 4350 BCE to 2025. The eruption record divides naturally into three phases: (1) the pre-caldera and caldera-forming supereruption, (2) post-caldera dome-building activity through the medieval period, and (3) the modern historical period of mild explosive activity. The dominant theme is the contrast between the single catastrophic VEI 7 event and the prolonged, low-intensity fumarolic and phreatic activity that has characterized the post-caldera era. Out of 30 recorded eruptions, the Akahoya event stands alone at VEI 7, two eruptions reached VEI 3, seven reached VEI 2, and the remainder were VEI 1 or lower. The pattern is typical of large calderas: a long repose period of diffuse, low-energy activity punctuated by infrequent but devastating paroxysmal eruptions. Eruption frequency has increased since the late 20th century, but exclusively at the Iodake dome, and all recent events have been phreatic or phreatomagmatic in character — steam-driven explosions rather than magmatic blasts.

subsections.title: The Akahoya Eruption (~7,300 Years Ago) — One of Earth's Largest Holocene Eruptions
subsections.content:
The defining event in Kikai's history is the Akahoya eruption, a VEI 7 cataclysm that occurred approximately 7,300 calendar years before present (recorded in the eruption database as ~4350 BCE). This eruption ranks among the three or four largest volcanic events of the entire Holocene epoch, comparable to the eruption that created Oregon's Crater Lake approximately 7,700 years ago.

The eruption ejected an estimated 150–170 km³ of rhyolitic material. The initial Plinian column may have reached heights of 30–40 km into the stratosphere, raining pumice and ash across the western Pacific. The most devastating phase involved pyroclastic flows — superheated clouds of gas and rock fragments — that surged outward from the collapsing eruption column and crossed the open sea for approximately 100 km, reaching the southern coastline of Kyushu. These flows moved across water, a phenomenon that is well-documented but still extraordinary in volcanology. The Akahoya ash layer, a distinctive orange-yellow tephra deposit, has been identified in geological sections throughout the Japanese archipelago, from Kyushu to Hokkaido — a distance of over 1,500 km — making it one of the most important chronostratigraphic markers in Japanese archaeology and geology.

The human toll is impossible to quantify precisely, but archaeological evidence indicates that the Jōmon culture of southern and central Kyushu was effectively obliterated. The region remained uninhabited for several centuries after the eruption, and when repopulation eventually occurred, the arriving communities showed distinct cultural differences from the pre-eruption inhabitants, suggesting that the original population was either killed or permanently displaced. The eruption fundamentally altered the trajectory of prehistoric Japanese civilization.

subsections.title: Post-Caldera Dome Growth (3rd–14th Century CE)
subsections.content: Following the caldera-forming event, volcanic activity at Kikai shifted to constructive dome-building. Eruptions in the centuries and millennia after the Akahoya event built the Iodake (Iwo-dake) rhyolitic lava dome and the Inamuradake basaltic scoria cone on the fragment of the caldera rim that forms Satsuma-Iōjima. Records indicate eruptions around 390 CE and 750 CE reached VEI 3, representing the most energetic post-caldera events. Additional eruptions occurred around 830, 1010, 1030, 1340, and 1430 CE, though their magnitudes are not well constrained. These events collectively built the volcanic landforms visible on Satsuma-Iōjima today. The Iodake dome, rising to 704 m (2,310 ft), remains the highest point of the Kikai caldera system above sea level.

subsections.title: The 1934–1935 Submarine Eruption — Birth of Shōwa-Iōjima
subsections.content: In September 1934, a submarine eruption began approximately 2 km east of Satsuma-Iōjima. Over the following months, repeated explosive activity broke the sea surface, building a new volcanic island that was named Shōwa-Iōjima (Iojima-Shintō). The eruption, rated VEI 2, produced Surtseyan-style explosions — violent interactions between magma and seawater — that sent columns of steam, ash, and rock fragments hundreds of meters into the air. By 1935, the new island had stabilized and has persisted as a permanent landmark, offering a vivid reminder that caldera systems like Kikai are far from extinct. The emergence of Shōwa-Iōjima demonstrated that magma remained accessible at shallow levels within the caldera.

subsections.title: Modern Phreatic Activity at Iodake (1988–2025)
subsections.content: Since 1988, Iodake has been the sole source of eruptive activity at Kikai. Mild phreatic and phreatomagmatic explosions occur at intervals of one to several years, typically producing ash plumes rising a few hundred meters to a few kilometers above the dome. Significant episodes include the 1998–1999 eruption (VEI 2), a series of events from 2000 to 2004 (multiple VEI 1–2 episodes), eruptions in 2013 (VEI 1), 2019 (VEI 2), and the most recent confirmed eruption in December 2025 (VEI 1). These events pose limited hazard beyond Satsuma-Iōjima itself, which has a resident population of only several hundred. However, they confirm the ongoing heat supply from a magmatic source beneath the caldera, keeping Kikai firmly classified as an active system.

current_status_and_monitoring.content:
Kikai caldera is classified as active and is monitored by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), which operates seismometers, GPS ground-deformation sensors, and a webcam on Satsuma-Iōjima. The most recent confirmed eruption occurred at Iodake crater in December 2025 (VEI 1). Fumarolic activity at Iodake is persistent, with sulfur dioxide emissions and elevated ground temperatures observed continuously. JMA maintains an alert level system for the volcano, which has been raised on multiple occasions during heightened unrest.

The discovery in 2018 of a giant lava dome (~32 km³) on the caldera floor by researchers from Kobe University's Ocean Bottom Exploration Center generated significant scientific interest. The dome's presence suggests that substantial volumes of magma have been emplaced within the caldera since the Akahoya eruption, though whether this represents a precursor to future large-scale activity remains a matter of active debate. Scientists emphasize that the probability of another VEI 7 eruption at Kikai in the near future is exceedingly low — likely less than 1% per century — but the consequences would be so severe that the risk cannot be dismissed. Japanese government contingency planning acknowledges caldera eruptions as a national-scale threat.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: The hazard profile of Kikai is bifurcated. On the immediate timescale, the primary hazards are phreatic explosions at Iodake, which can produce ballistic projectiles, small pyroclastic surges, and minor ashfall affecting Satsuma-Iōjima and potentially aviation routes in the region. These hazards are localized and manageable with standard monitoring and evacuation protocols. On the long timescale, the potential for a repeat caldera-forming eruption represents one of the most severe natural hazards facing Japan. A VEI 7 eruption at Kikai could produce pyroclastic flows reaching Kyushu's southern coast (home to cities including Kagoshima, population ~600,000) within approximately one hour. Tephra fall of 10 cm or more could blanket an area encompassing much of southern Japan, disrupting agriculture, infrastructure, transportation, and water supplies for tens of millions of people. A 2014 study by Kobe University estimated that a worst-case caldera eruption in the Kyushu region could ultimately affect over 100 million people and cause catastrophic damage to Japan's economy and food supply. The Japanese government's Cabinet Office has identified large-scale caldera eruptions as a scenario for which current disaster preparedness is fundamentally insufficient.

geography_and_physical_description.content: The Kikai caldera is an approximately 19-km-wide, roughly elliptical depression whose floor lies beneath the surface of the East China Sea. The caldera rim is mostly submerged, but two fragments rise above sea level: Satsuma-Iōjima (also called Tokara-Iōjima), a small island measuring approximately 3 × 6 km that forms the northwestern rim, and Take-shima, an uninhabited islet to the east. Satsuma-Iōjima's terrain is dominated by two volcanic structures: Iodake (704 m / 2,310 ft), a rhyolitic lava dome at the eastern end known for its persistent fumarolic emissions and sulfurous yellow discoloration, and Inamuradake (236 m), a basaltic scoria cone in the island's center. The two peaks are separated by a low saddle. The island's coastline features dramatic sea cliffs, thermal springs, and discolored nearshore waters caused by submarine fumarolic venting. Shōwa-Iōjima, the small island born from the 1934–35 eruption, lies approximately 2 km east of Satsuma-Iōjima and covers an area of about 200 × 100 m.

climate_and_global_impact.content: The Akahoya eruption approximately 7,300 years ago would have injected massive quantities of sulfur dioxide and fine ash into the stratosphere, with the potential for measurable hemispheric cooling. However, because this eruption occurred during prehistory, no written records document its climatic effects. Paleoclimate proxies — including tree-ring records, ice cores, and pollen analyses — from the broader North Pacific region have been examined for signatures of the event, but distinguishing its signal from other climate forcing factors over such long timescales is challenging. By comparison, the 1815 eruption of Tambora (VEI 7, approximately 41 km³ DRE) produced the global 'Year Without a Summer' in 1816. The Akahoya eruption's estimated 150–170 km³ DRE output suggests its climatic impact may have been even more severe, potentially cooling global temperatures by 1–2°C for several years. This places Kikai alongside Tambora, Mount Mazama, and the Toba supereruption as one of the most climatically significant volcanic events of the late Quaternary.

cultural_significance.content: Kikai's cultural significance is deeply intertwined with Japanese archaeology and the understanding of prehistoric civilizations. The Akahoya eruption is one of the most important events in Japanese archaeological chronology — the distinctive orange-yellow Akahoya tephra layer serves as a dating marker in stratigraphic sections across Japan, allowing archaeologists to correlate sites from Kyushu to Hokkaido. The destruction of the southern Kyushu Jōmon culture by the eruption has been cited as one of the most dramatic examples of volcanic catastrophe reshaping human history. In modern Japanese culture, Satsuma-Iōjima has a quieter but notable presence. The island's hot springs, sulfurous landscape, and dramatic volcanic scenery attract small numbers of visitors, though access is limited to irregular ferry service from Kagoshima. The island's name, incorporating 'Iō' (sulfur), reflects its volcanic character. The Japanese public became more aware of Kikai's threat potential following the 2018 lava dome discovery and subsequent media coverage discussing the possibility of future caldera eruptions.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Satsuma-Iōjima is accessible by ferry from Kagoshima Port, though service is infrequent (typically a few sailings per week) and subject to weather cancellations. The island offers a unique volcanic experience for adventurous travelers willing to navigate limited infrastructure. Key attractions include views of Iodake's fumarolic vents from safe vantage points, the Higashi Onsen coastal hot spring (where volcanic heat warms seawater pools at the shore), and panoramic views across the caldera from the island's elevated points. The island's small community maintains a handful of guesthouses. Visitors should be aware that JMA volcanic alert levels may restrict access to certain areas near Iodake, and that sulfurous gas emissions can be hazardous in enclosed valleys. There is no public infrastructure on Shōwa-Iōjima. The best time to visit is spring through autumn, when seas are calmer and ferry service more reliable.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Kikai lies at the northern end of the Ryukyu Volcanic Arc, within a region of intense volcanic activity in southwestern Japan. Approximately 115 km to the north lies Sakurajima (Aira caldera), one of the world's most persistently active volcanoes, which erupts hundreds of times per year. Further north on Kyushu, Aso caldera — another massive caldera system with its own history of VEI 7 eruptions — dominates the landscape of central Kumamoto Prefecture. To the south along the Ryukyu chain, the volcanic islands of Suwanosejima and Nakanoshima exhibit frequent Strombolian activity. Together, these volcanoes form part of the broader Pacific Ring of Fire subduction system and represent one of the densest concentrations of large caldera systems on Earth.

etymology.content: The name 'Kikai' (鬼界) translates approximately as 'demon world' or 'spirit boundary' in Japanese, an evocative name that may reflect the intimidating volcanic landscape of the caldera islands — the sulfurous gases, discolored waters, and barren volcanic terrain. The island name 'Iōjima' (硫黄島) means 'sulfur island,' a direct reference to the pervasive sulfur deposits around Iodake. The prefix 'Satsuma' distinguishes it from the more famous Iwo Jima (Iōtō) in the Bonin Islands to the east.

faqs.question: What is the Kikai caldera?
faqs.answer: Kikai is a large, mostly submarine volcanic caldera approximately 19 km wide, located in the East China Sea about 50 km south of Kyushu, Japan. It was formed by a catastrophic VEI 7 eruption approximately 7,300 years ago that ejected 150–170 km³ of rhyolitic material and ranks among the largest volcanic events of the Holocene. Today, the caldera rim breaks the surface as the islands of Satsuma-Iōjima and Take-shima. Ongoing mild eruptions from the Iodake lava dome on Satsuma-Iōjima confirm that the system remains volcanically active. The caldera is part of the Ryukyu Volcanic Arc, formed by subduction of the Philippine Sea Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate.

faqs.question: Is Kikai caldera still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Kikai caldera is classified as an active volcanic system. The most recent confirmed eruption occurred at Iodake crater on Satsuma-Iōjima in December 2025, rated VEI 1. Mild phreatic and phreatomagmatic explosions from Iodake have occurred repeatedly since 1988, with notable episodes in 1998–99, 2000–2004, 2013, 2019, and 2024. Persistent fumarolic activity, sulfur dioxide emissions, and discolored nearshore waters provide continuous evidence of a heat source beneath the caldera. The Japan Meteorological Agency monitors Kikai with seismometers, GPS sensors, and webcams. While the probability of a repeat caldera-forming eruption is considered extremely low, the system's ongoing activity confirms it is far from extinct.

faqs.question: How big was the Kikai eruption 7,300 years ago?
faqs.answer: The Akahoya eruption of Kikai caldera approximately 7,300 years ago was rated VEI 7 on the Volcanic Explosivity Index, making it one of the largest volcanic eruptions of the entire Holocene epoch. The eruption ejected an estimated 150–170 km³ of dense rock equivalent of rhyolitic material. For comparison, the 1991 eruption of Pinatubo (VEI 6) ejected roughly 10 km³, and the 1815 eruption of Tambora (VEI 7) ejected approximately 41 km³. Pyroclastic flows traveled 100 km across the sea to reach Kyushu, and ashfall covered Japan from Kyushu to Hokkaido. The eruption depopulated southern Kyushu for centuries.

faqs.question: Could Kikai caldera erupt again?
faqs.answer: Kikai caldera could theoretically produce another large eruption, though scientists consider the probability of a VEI 7 event in the near future to be extremely low — likely less than 1% per century. Ongoing mild eruptions at Iodake confirm that magma is present beneath the caldera, and the 2018 discovery of a 32 km³ lava dome on the caldera floor demonstrates continued magmatic emplacement. However, the repose interval between caldera-forming eruptions at systems like Kikai is typically tens of thousands of years. More likely in the short term are continued phreatic explosions at Iodake. The Japan Meteorological Agency continuously monitors Kikai for any signs of escalating unrest.

faqs.question: Where is Kikai caldera located?
faqs.answer: Kikai caldera is located in the East China Sea at coordinates 30.793°N, 130.305°E, approximately 50 km south of the southern tip of Kyushu, Japan's third-largest island. It lies near the northern end of the Ryukyu Island chain, within Kagoshima Prefecture. The nearest major city is Kagoshima, roughly 115 km to the north. The caldera is mostly submerged beneath the sea surface, with only the small islands of Satsuma-Iōjima (3 × 6 km) and Take-shima rising above water as fragments of the caldera rim.

faqs.question: What is the lava dome discovered inside Kikai caldera?
faqs.answer: In 2018, researchers from Kobe University's Ocean Bottom Exploration Center announced the discovery of a massive lava dome on the seafloor inside Kikai caldera. The dome measures approximately 32 km³ in volume and 10 km across, making it one of the largest volcanic domes known on Earth. It was detected using underwater seismic surveys, sonar mapping, and remotely operated vehicle observations. The dome's composition appears to be rhyolitic, consistent with Kikai's eruptive history. The discovery indicates that significant volumes of magma have been emplaced within the caldera since the Akahoya eruption, though scientists emphasize this does not indicate an imminent large eruption.

faqs.question: Can you visit Kikai caldera?
faqs.answer: The primary way to experience Kikai caldera is by visiting Satsuma-Iōjima, the inhabited island that forms part of the caldera rim. The island is accessible by ferry from Kagoshima Port, with sailings several times per week (approximately 4 hours each way). Visitors can view Iodake's active fumaroles from safe distances, bathe in the volcanic coastal hot spring at Higashi Onsen, and explore the island's dramatic volcanic landscape. Accommodation is limited to a small number of guesthouses. Access to certain areas near Iodake may be restricted depending on the current JMA volcanic alert level. Shōwa-Iōjima and the submerged caldera itself are not accessible to visitors.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Kikai?
faqs.answer: Kikai is classified as a caldera — a large volcanic depression formed by the collapse of a magma chamber following a massive eruption. At approximately 19 km in diameter, it ranks among the larger calderas in the Japanese archipelago. Within the caldera, multiple eruption centers exist, including the Iodake rhyolitic lava dome and the Inamuradake basaltic scoria cone. The dominant rock type is rhyolite, which is highly silica-rich and associated with the most explosive eruption styles. This classification distinguishes Kikai from typical stratovolcanoes or shield volcanoes, placing it in the same category as systems like Yellowstone, Taupo, and Aira (Sakurajima).
